item.title: Why Ethernet is Cheaper
item.description: You probably know that T1 and DS3 lines have become much cheaper in recent years. But for those who need bandwidth of 10 Mbps or more, there’s an even better deal: Ethernet. While you might know Ethernet as a local area network protocol, it’s now a wide area network protocol too. This means your carrier can provide an Ethernet connection that plugs directly into your existing network router or switch. You might see it called Ethernet WAN, Metro Ethernet, Carrier Ethernet, or Ethernet Transport.

item.title: Fractional and Full Gigabit Ethernet Options

item.title: Ethernet Internet Service Access For Business
item.description: Having internet access is essential for businesses today, whether they operate primarily online or from a physical location. It’s how businesses connect with customers, suppliers, remote employees, and even their own offices. But is the internet service used by businesses the same as what individuals use at home? There are actually different options for internet service, each with unique features: dedicated or shared bandwidth, symmetrical or asymmetrical speeds, wired or wireless connection, copper or fiber optic cables, and varying levels of bandwidth and cost.

item.title: Technologies That Should Stay in 2012
item.description: While technological advancements are incremental, they often force us to upgrade to the latest devices while clinging to older ones for compatibility.
